The Web Speech API remains the natural choice for this task for now, but the ML approach will only continue to offer greater opportunities over time.

  • ğŸ‘¾ In other gamedev news, you can see the latest js13kGames winners too. It's amazing what some people can put together in such little space.

  • ğŸ˜† It turns out obfuscating JavaScript and then compressing it doesn't have a great outcome in terms of size reduction. Fun though?

  • ğŸ¨ The Node.js project has an official mascot design contest.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • TanStack Query v5 â€“ Query-led declarative state management and data fetching.

  • Storybook 7.5 â€“ Frontend component dev tool. Now with Vite 5 and Lit 3 support, faster starts, and Angular-focused improvements.

  • Lit 3.0 â€“ Build agnostic components on top of modern Web standards.

  • Rockpack 4.0 â€“ React app starter/generator.

  • Astro 3.3, Biome 1.3, and Bun 1.0.6.

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

The Nuances of Base64 Encoding Strings in JavaScript â€” Base64 provides a way to represent binary data in ASCII strings which may be safer to share and store in certain situations. Matt looks at how to do Base64 encoding and decoding in JavaScript and some areas where you need to take special care.

Matt Joseph

event.target.closest â€” If youâ€™ve not used closest, itâ€™s worth being aware of this way to return the closest DOM node that matches a specified CSS selector (based upon traversal of the DOM tree up towards the root).

Jeremy Keith

UI Component Library for Project Management and Resource Planning â€” Level up your UI with advanced data grids, calendars, schedulers, and Gantt charts.

Bryntum sponsor

â–¶  Prototyping a JavaScript JIT Compiler â€” It almost feels like building a JIT compiler has become the new â€œhello worldâ€ (ok, slight exaggeration) but this 80 minute screencast is fascinating (and, amazingly, demystifies some of the magic) if you have the time and inclination.

Andreas Kling

ğŸ¤© Andreas is such a top notch developer, he's developed a JavaScript-capable browser called Ladybird for his own OS: SerenityOS.

New Angular 17 Feature: Deferred Loading â€” Next level lazy-loading demonstrated by using a Signal-based and other examples.

Gergely Szerovay

Do We Need State Management in Angular?
BalÃ¡zs KovÃ¡cs

How to Escape CSS Selectors in JavaScript
Stefan Judis

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Postgres.js 3.4: A Full-Featured Postgres Client for All â€” Now working with several JavaScript platforms (Node, Deno, Bun, and, as of this release, Cloudflare), this high performance Postgres library offers realtime change subscription, dynamic query building via special template literals, high availability support via multi-host connection URLs, async cursors, and more.

Rasmus Porsager

New Wallaby.js Logpoints: Quick & Easy Logging, Simply Set a Breakpoint â€” No setup needed, real-time feedback in your editor. Class & function support allows you to quickly log runtime values for all lines in a class or function.

Wallaby Team sponsor

PureImage: A Pure JS HTML Canvas 2D for Node.js â€” If you want a browser-like 2D canvas experience in Node but without any native dependencies, this is for you. You can then save the output to PNG or JPEG. (node-canvas is the long-standing popular choice in this same area but relies upon Cairo as a dependency.)

Josh Marinacci

Cronicle: A Cron System with a Web Front End â€” Describing itself as â€˜a fancy cron replacementâ€™, Cronicle is a task scheduler and runner built in Node.js with a web-based UI.

Joseph Huckaby

Timeline JS: Create Useful Timelines for the Web â€” Built by a journalism lab at a university, this is not aimed at expert developers but folks focused on telling a story or presenting some data online. Hereâ€™s an example showing a timeline of â€˜revolutionary user interfaces.â€™

Northwestern University Knight Lab

Add Figma Like Collaborative Features Without Re-Architecting Your App

Ably sponsor

table-saw: A Small Web Component for Responsive HTML Tables â€” Inspired by a jQuery plugin with a similar name. Check out some some demos.

Zach Leatherman

  • eslint-plugin-regexp 2.0 â€“ ESLint plugin to find regex related issues. (Interactive demo.)

  • little-rat â€“ Chrome extension to monitor (and block) other extensions' network calls.

  • Sortable 3.0 â€“ Make tables sortable with class="sortable"

  • AdminJS 7.3 â€“ Automatic admin interface for Node apps.

  • Shoelace 2.10 â€“ Suite of elegant web components.

  • Recharts 2.9 â€“ React and D3 charting library.

  • Fable 4.3 â€“ F# to JavaScript compiler.

ğŸ And one for luck..

QX82: Retro-Inspired Computing in a JavaScript Library â€” With a name riffing on the ZX81 computer, QX82â€™s goal is to let you create retro-feeling (mid 80s, to be precise) games and experiences with JavaScript. Itâ€™s not a runtime or emulator - you could bake this into your own web site, if you wanted.

Bruno Oliveira

âœï¸ Due to being on the road at an event, this is a more compact and bijou issue but I'm back at full pace next week ğŸ˜…
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

JavaScript Weekly

Speeding Up the JS Ecosystem: The Barrel File Debacle â€” Marvin continues his tour through the world of JavaScript performance fixes with a look at how some innocent looking code can make tools run slower than they should. Test runners and many import cycle detection tools are most affected.

Marvin Hagemeister

ğŸŒŠ  Building a Water/Fluid Simulation in JavaScript â€” Hard to explain, but a lot of thought and care has gone into this tutorial of sorts. The live demos are nice, too. Uses p5.js behind the scenes.

Kenichi Yoneda

Strongly Typed and in the â›…: Meet EdgeDB 4.0 â€” EdgeDB is an open-source database focused on developer experience. It features a high-level, modern data model, integrated schema migrations, and a TypeScript query builder that makes it easy to write advanced, fast queries, putting ORMs to shame.

EdgeDB sponsor

Angular and Qwik's Creator on How JS Frameworks Handle Reactivity â€” A summary of MiÅ¡ko Heveryâ€™s keynote from the International JavaScript Conference looking at reactivity across the major frameworks.

Loraine Lawson (The New Stack)

A Web Server â€˜Hello Worldâ€™ Benchmark: Go vs Node vs Nim vs Bun â€” The standard disclaimer applies: benchmarks are difficult and donâ€™t always measure what you should care about.

Daniel Lemire

  • ğŸ‘€ Simon Willison has put together a fantastic live demo (in notebook format) showing off how to do client-side object detection in images using solely JavaScript and a neural network. (Note: Be aware this uses a lot of CPU and may slow your browser down.)

  • â–¶ï¸ ViteConf 2023 took place last week and some of the talks are already available on YouTube. ğŸ¦ One key bit of news is about Rolldown, a Rust port of Rollup, meaning Vite will get even faster in the medium term.

  • âš™ï¸ Stephen RÃ¶ttger of the V8 team has blogged about efforts to enable control-flow integrity (CFI) in V8, essentially a way to reduce the ability of nefarious third parties to exploit V8's control flow in order to trigger arbitrary shellcode.

  • âš ï¸ A look at the potential dangers of regular expressions in JavaScript.

  • ğŸ‘¾ An interesting post mortem of a game built in just 13KB for the JS13K contest.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • Electron 27 â€“ The cross-platform desktop app toolkit gains Chromium 118, Node.js 18.17.1, and V8 11.8, but loses macOS 10.13/14 support.

  • Fresh 1.5 â€“ A Deno-native framework for building full-stack webapps. v1.5 adds support for partials â€“ the ability to update a portion of an existing page.

  • Parcel 2.10 â€“ The zero-config build tool gets some serious performance improvements (7x faster on large projects). Devon Govett wrote ğŸ¦ a Twitter thread explaining how.

  • Bun 1.0.5 â€“ Mostly bug fixes and gentle improvements for the performance-oriented JS runtime. No HTTP/2 yet, but it's just around the corner..

  • Solid 1.8 â€“ Declarative and performant reactivity for building UIs.

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Evidence: Reports Synced to Your Data with SQL and Markdown â€” An open source, code-based alternative to drag-and-drop business intelligence tools. â–¶ï¸ This nine minute screencast does a good job at showing off what it can do.

Evidence

Payload 2.0: A Headless CMS Platform Built on Node â€” A Node-based headless CMS providing an app framework-like experience, including a customizable React-based admin system, GraphQL or REST APIs, flexible auth and file upload systems, etc. v2.0 introduces Postgres support (in addition to MongoDB), Vite support, and a new rich text editor. GitHub repo.

James Mikrut
